newsitem.title: USA: U.S. FDIC proposes insurance rule clarifications.
newsitem.headline: U.S. FDIC proposes insurance rule clarifications.

text.p: The U.S. Federal Deposit Insurance Corp issued a proposal on Tuesday to simplify and clarify some of the agency's insurance rules.
The agency said the new rules would include simple examples to enable an average depositor to quickly understand what types of coverage are available.
The proposal would also give the agency more flexibility to insure third-party deposits made by law firms, real estate agents, title companies and other businesses on behalf of customers.
Also, the proposal would create a six-month grace period after a depositor's death for beneficiaries to rearrange inherited accounts if necessary to avoid going over the $100,000 insurance limit.

The agency's board of directors instructed its staff to study whether deposit insurance coverage would be significantly expanded if the rules governing joint accounts and payable-on-death accounts were further simplified. Such simplification was not proposed on Tuesday.
The agency will accept written comments on the proposal for 90 days.
